metadata.title: On nonlinear forced vibration of nano cantilever-based biosensor via couple stress theory

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Mechanical Systems and Signal Processing
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /ymssp
On nonlinear forced vibration of nano cantilever-based biosensor via couple stress theory
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ymssp.2019.03.020 0888-3270/ 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail address: omid.rahmani@znu.ac.ir (O. Rahmani). 1 Associate professor.
Saman Jabbari Behrouz, Omid Rahmani ⇑,1, S. Amirhossein Hosseini Smart Structures and New Advanced Materials Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Zanjan, Zanjan, Iran
a r t i c l e i n f o a b s t r a c t
Article history: Received 2 November 2018 Received in revised form 11 February 2019 Accepted 16 March 2019
Keywords: Nonlinear vibration Biosensor Multiple scales Couple stress theory Frequency-response curve
In this paper, the nonlinear forced vibration of a piezoelectrically driven micro/nano cantilever-based biosensor is investigated via couple stress theory. The origin of nonlinear equations is the curvature, which causes cubic nonlinearities in the differential equation. Due to the dimensions of the structure and its size-dependent behavior, the governing equation is derived based on couple stress theory. In order to obtain the frequencyresponse equation, the differential equation is solved with the assumption of small displacement, damping coefficient, and excitation amplitude by the multiple scales method. Then, the amplitude of the response and the nonlinear resonance frequency based on the classical and couple stress theory are presented and the effect of the absorption of the biological layer on the frequency variation of the two theories is compared with each other. Also, to achieve high sensitivity resulting from optimal dimensions, the variation of beam frequency for various dimensions has been studied. Finally, by studying the bifurcation points and half-stable region, the jump phenomenon in amplitude caused by biologic layer absorption as a strategy for biological detection has been investigated and the results validated qualitatively with previous studies.
2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The sensor is a device which transforms physical phenomena into measurable signals. The term biosensor which was first appeared in the 1960s, is a tool for many purposes, such as clinical diagnosis, food contamination, environmental and pharmaceutical use. The use of common clinical methods has limitations, such as response time and the high cost of doing operations; therefore, the development of an efficient method as a diagnostic tool and biological molecular identification technology is required [1,2]. A micro/nano cantilever-based sensor is a new tool for direct identification of molecular interactions with respect to the inherent properties of matter (label-free detection) such as mass, size, etc. The main strategy of sensors based on nano-mechanical converters, and in particular the cantilevers, is to transform chemical reactions into motion or mechanical deformations in nano/micrometer dimensions. The advantages of these sensors are their small size, portability, very low cost of production, use of the minimum sample, and diagnosis without the labeling. The strategy of cantilever biosensors is based on two approaches: the static approach, which is based on the bending measurement influenced by the surface stress caused by absorption, and the dynamic approach, in which the concentration of a sample is obtained by measuring the variation in the resonance frequency of the beam caused by the absorption of biological material [3,4].
Cantilever-based sensors, which are based on static approach often have several advantages over dynamic mode, but to identify the mass in order of a single molecule only the dynamic method can be used in a nanoscale beam [5]. It should be noted that among the three key metrics of sensors which include response time, selectivity, and sensitivity, only the last case is dependent on the identification scheme [6]. Therefore, studying the effective variables on the efficiency of the approach such as mechanical behavior at nano and micro scales, geometry, and environment will provide a suitable platform for providing high sensitivity sensors.
Several studies today confirm the difference between classical mechanics and the mechanics of micro and nanostructures. The emphasis of these studies is on size-dependent behavior at the micro and nanoscales. Couple stress theory is one of the theories governing these structures. It reduces to the classical theory by increasing the size of the object. This theory has attracted many scholars over the past century, so that the Cosserat brothers [7], Mindlin [8], Koiter [9], Eringen [10], Yang [11], Hadjesfandiari [12] and their colleagues have discussed and expanded the theory of couple stress in their era. According to the results of numerous experiments [13], it can be confidently said today that the effect of the interactions of micro/nano structures (the origin of the couple stress theory) is not negligible. Several studies have since been done in this field. A review of the available literature shows that the research on the couple stress theory can be divided into linear and nonlinear categories, each of which can be divided further into the two groups of static and dynamic analysis. The linear static and dynamic analysis of microscale beams have been studied frequently. Researchers who have focused on static analysis of the beam [14–18] have claimed the reduction of the beam deflection in the theory of couple stress relative to classical theory. Also, studies in the second category, i.e. dynamic analysis of beam based on couple stress theory [19–23] have found that frequency increases due to this theory. In addition, some researchers have investigated the static and dynamic behavior of the beam simultaneously using the couple stress theory [24–26]. They have had similar results. It should also be noted that all of these researchers claimed that the difference in deflection and frequency predicted by the classical and nonclassical theory is very small when the beam thickness is comparable to the material length scale parameter.
On the other hand, experiments show that the effects of nonlinearities are very significant on the behavior of nano and micro-mechanical tools even in the absence of large deformations [27]. Hence several researchers have focused on geometric nonlinearity. Some of them acknowledged the higher accuracy of nonlinear models as compared to linear models. Studies of nonlinear oscillations can be categorized by two methods: one is free and forced vibration, the other is numerical and analytical solution. Free vibrations of beams have been investigated numerically by methods such as differential quadrature, Runge–Kutta and Ritz [28–31]. On the other hand, several studies have focused on the numerical solution of forced vibration of beams [32–34] based on the Matlab-Simulink and pseudo-arclength method. In such studies, closed form solution for natural frequency and frequency-response equation is not provided; while in the free vibration category, Mahmoodi et al. [35] investigated non-linear mode shapes and natural frequencies for a class of one-dimensional continuous damped systems with weak cubic inertia, and damping and stiffness non-linearities. They finally used the method of multiple scales to extend the nonlinear mode shapes and natural frequencies. Nazemnezhad and Hosseini-Hashemi [36] investigated the nonlinear free vibration of functionally graded (FG) nanobeams with immovable ends. They established the analytical solution for the nonlinear natural frequency using the method of multiple scales. Shen et al. [37] studied the large amplitude vibration of functionally graded graphene-reinforced composite laminated plates resting on an elastic foundation and in thermal environments. In this study, the motion equations were solved by a two-step perturbation technique to determine the nonlinear frequencies of the laminated plates.
In the forced vibration category, Mahmoodi et al. [38] focused on analysis of nonlinear vibration via a directly excited cantilever beam modeled as an inextensible viscoelastic Euler–Bernoulli beam. They presented the frequency-response equation by the multiple scales method. Zhang et al. [39] investigated the steady-state periodic response of an axially moving viscoelastic beam. After the discretization of the governing equation, they solved it by multiple scales method and presented the frequency-response equation. Shoshtari and Rafiee [40] analyzed the nonlinear forced vibration of the clamped, functionally graded beam. In this research, a multiple scales solution was used to present the frequency response curve. Youzera and Meftah [41] studied the damping and forced vibrations of three-layered, symmetric laminated composite beams. They presented the frequency-response curves using the harmonic balance method and discussed various geometric and material properties.
As discussed above, couple stress theory should be considered when working at micro/nano dimensions. Also, nonlinear modeling gives more accurate results as compared to linear models. So considering the nonlinear model based on couple stress theory will present a more accurate analysis. Hence, this kind of work has attracted the attention of researchers in recent years. Pseudo-arclength as a numerical method has also been used frequently for forced vibration analysis. Some researchers have used it to present a frequency-response curve for various models based on the couple stress theory [42– 44]. Free vibration is also studied with various other numerical techniques, such as differential quadrature and He’s method [45,46]. Furthermore, Asghari et al. [47] examined the free vibration and static bending of the Timoshenko microcantilever based on couple stress theory. They used von Kármán nonlinear strain to drive the equation of motion and solved it using the multiple scales method. Mirjavad et al.[48] studied the nonlinear free and forced vibration of a functionally graded graphene nanoplatelet reinforced microbeam based on couple stress theory. In this study, the beam has geometrical imperfection which is rested on a non-linear elastic substrate. They solved the differential equation includes cubic and quadratic nonlinearity using harmonic balance method. Finally, Researchers claimed that the increasing couple stress parameter makes structure stiffer due to particles micro-rotations. Xia et al. [49] investigated the size-dependent nonlinear bending, buckling, and free vibration of the microcantilever. In this study, the frequency of vibration of the beam was obtained using the
multiple scales method. They showed that the static and dynamic behavior of the beamwas strongly influenced by the linear or nonlinear model of the beam. It should be noted that in all the mentioned research which considered the nonlinear and couple stress model simultaneously, the origin of nonlinearity is the von Kármán strain.
As discussed above, microcantilever-based biosensors can be used for detecting biological material through the dynamical approach. Hence, some studies focused on this model for the analysis of sensor response. Ziegler [50] reviewed the mathematical model of the cantilever-based biosensor. In order to obtain the frequency, he used the classical linear model of the Euler–Bernoulli beam with damping. Afshari and Jalili [51] studied the nonlinear vibration of covered microcantilevers with biological material. In this study, the origin of nonlinearity is the nonlinear curvature and the influence of the biological layer has been considered according to the Lennard-Jones potential energy. Finally, researchers solved the equation of motion numerically and presented their results. They showed that by reducing the dimensions of the beam, its sensitivity to mass absorption increases. In a more complete model, Mahmoodi et al. [52] studied the nonlinear vibrations of a piezoelectrically driven microcantilever beam in the presence of a biological monolayer. They solved the equation of motion using MatlabSimulink and then investigated the influence of the biological layer on the frequency variation. Jain and Alam [6] reviewed various ways of detecting biomolecules using nanocantilevers. According to their expression, the sensitivity of biological sensors in addition to the discovery strategy depends on the linear or non-linear behavior of the cantilever. Also, they noted that considering the jump phenomenon at critical stages such as bifurcation points will provide highly sensitive biosensors. Eltaher et al. [53] studied the nanobeam sensor for measuring the zeptogram mass. In this study, they used the linear Euler– Bernoulli beam model based on nonlocal theory and investigated the change in frequency due to absorption for various nonlocal parameter.
Many investigations have been carried out on the vibrating of cantilever-based biosensor. However, most of these studies are performed employing linear spring and mass (discrete) model. On the other hand there are few studies that considered complete model (including all components, such as piezoelectric and biological layers) of continues system, but based on classical theories. Although the material used in the biosensor beam is usually silicon and has size-dependent behavior. Hence the difference between classical and non-classical theory in this type of beam is significant. In this paper, for the first time, the nonlinear forced vibrations of the Euler–Bernoulli beam covered by piezoelectric and biological monolayer based on skew-symmetric couple stress theory is investigated. By solving the nonlinear differential equation via the analytical method of multiple scales, the effect of geometric parameters, the type of linear or nonlinear behavior, and the influence of use of classical and non-classical theories on the sensitivity of biological sensors has been studied. Also, the jump phenomenon in the nonlinear model as a new scheme for detecting biological material is investigated.

sections.heading: 2. Mathematical modeling
sections.text:
As shown in Fig. 1a, a beam of length L, width b, and thickness h is assumed to be covered by piezoelectric material. As stated before, piezoelectric material is used as an actuator. The biological layer will be absorbed to the beam as illustrated in Fig. 1b, and hence the frequency and amplitude of the vibration will get changed. Therefore, these changes will be studied by considering the nonlinear regime and the appropriate theory of nano/microstructures such as couple stress theory in the following sections.
Nonlinear geometry is divided into two parts: the von Kármán nonlinear strain and nonlinear curvature [54]. In the second type of nonlinear geometry, the curvature of the beam is more precisely related to the axial and transversal deformation. Several papers have exploited this geometry to derive the governing equations of the beam [32,35,38,52,54–56], and some of them have confirmed the accuracy of this geometry by conducting experiments and comparing them with the results of the theory [38,56]. Therefore, according to Fig. 2, the elongation of the beam and bending angle after the deflection can be written as [57]:
e ¼ ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi 1þ @u

For beams with clamped-free or clamped-sliding boundary conditions, and without external axial load, the mid-plane stretching is zero [57]. So, by employment of the inextensibility condition, Eq. (1) can be expressed as:

Using the Taylor series expansion, and considering @u=@xð Þ 1 due to infinitesimal strain and also assuming moderately large transverse motion, the relation between axial and transverse displacement can be written as:

sections.heading: 2.1. Strain energy
sections.text:
In couple stress theory, the strain energy for a linear elastic material is given by [12]:
U ¼ 1 2 Z v ðrijeij þmijvijÞdv ð8Þ
where vij; rij; mij; eij denote the curvature, force stress, couple stress, and strain tensor respectively. It should be noted that the skew-symmetric couple stress theory has been considered here. In one-dimensional problems such as beam, modified couple stress theory and skew-symmetric couple stress theory are the same even though it can be shown that curvature tensor is skew-symmetric [12,58]. The mentioned tensors can be defined as [12]:
rij ¼ kemmdij þ 2leij ð9Þ

sections.heading: 2.2. Piezoelectric potential energy
sections.text:
Any physical quantity that can be described with two variables is called a physical domain. Whenever a change in the state of a domain causes a change in the state of another domain, this situation signifies the coupling of two domains. Piezoelectric materials that have electromechanical coupling can experience mechanical deformation under polarization conditions, and also can experience polarization under mechanical load. This coupling can be expressed as [59]:
eu ¼ suqrq þ duiei ð21Þ
where d is the piezoelectric charge constant, r; e; e represent the stress, strain, and electrical field vectors respectively, and s denotes the compliance coefficient matrix. Also, the matrix form of Eq. (21) for transversely isotropic materials can be written as [59]:

sections.heading: 2.3. Biological potential energy
sections.text:
As noted in the introduction, the beam is covered by a layer of receptor molecules. In other words, each target molecule will be absorbed into its own receptor (such as antigen and antibody). This absorption, due to intermolecular interactions, leads to bending the beam in static mode and changing the frequency in dynamical fashion. To calculate the effect of molecular potentials on the mechanical behavior of the beam, the Lennard-Jones potential is used. Hence, the intermolecular potential that is based on the attraction and repulsion between molecules can be expressed as [60]:
S ¼ 4 2 s r 12 s r 6 ð30Þ
where r is the distance between the particles, 2 is the depth of the potential well, and s is the finite distance at which the inter-particle potential is zero. Hence, according to the arrangement of the molecules shown in Fig. 3 and the deformed geometry of the beam as shown in Fig. 2, the Lennard-Jones potential can be rewritten as:
S ¼ 8 2 Z L 0

9>= >;dx ð31Þ
It should be noted that according to the experiments, only the first layer absorbed on the surface of the micro/nanobeam upon bending and the variation of the vibration frequency have a significant effect. Therefore, the simple model mentioned in Fig. 3 can be considered [60].
By applying the two-variable Taylor expansion to Eq. (31), the final formof the biologic layer potential can be formulated as:
S ¼ Z L 0 k1 @w @x 2 þ k2 @w @x 4 2k1 ! dx ð32Þ

sections.heading: 2.4. External work and kinetic energy
sections.text:
It must be said that the external work done by damper can be neglected because of small damping coefficient of the air, but since the goal is to plot the frequency-response curve, regardless of the damping, it leads to the desire of the amplitude to be infinite. External work due to damping can be expressed as:
F ¼ cd Z L 0 @w @t w dx ð37Þ
where cd denotes the viscous damping coefficient. The kinetic energy of the system can also be stated as
K ¼ 1 2 mt Z @u @t 2 þ @w @t 2" # dx ð38Þ
where
mt ¼ qpAp þ qbAb þms ð39Þ
It should be said that q is the density of the material andms is mass of biolayer that should be considered after absorption. As stated about the inextensibility condition and its results, by integrating Eq. (5) and substituting what has been achieved into Eq. (38), the kinetic energy in terms of one variable can be expressed as:
K ¼ 1 2 mt Z l 0 ð@w @t Þ 2 þ 1 2 @ @t Z @w @x 2 dx " #28< : 9= ;dx ð40Þ

sections.heading: 3.1. Frequency response
sections.text:
As seen, the cubic nonlinear terms resulting from nonlinear curvature appear in the partial differential form of the equation. Therefore, the Galerkin scheme is employed to discretize the partial differential equation into an ordinary differential equation. Hence, the variables of the equation can be separated as follows:
wðx; tÞ ¼ YðxÞTðtÞ ð46Þ
where YðxÞ is the linear mode shape of Euler–Bernoulli beam for clamped-free boundary condition. This function can be expressed as follows [61]:
YðxÞ ¼ An cosbnx coshbnxð Þ cosbnl coshbnlð Þ cosbnl coshbnlð Þ sinbnx sinhbnxð Þ
ð47Þ
where An is a constant obtained by using the orthogonality condition, and bn can be calculated from Eq. (48), which is known as the frequency equation:
cosbnlcoshbnlþ 1 ¼ 0 ð48Þ

Eq. (49) is a nonlinear ordinary differential equation that can be solved by employing the multiple scales method (MMS). The multiple scales method has been developed for systems with small nonlinearities. Therefore, in order to take advantage of this method, the coefficients of nonlinear expressions should be scaled. Hence, it can be assumed that displacement is in the order of eg [62], so that:
T ¼ egr ð56Þ
aeg€r þ begr þ ce3gr3 þ de3g r _r2 þ r2€r þ ee3g _r ¼ fe3gcosðXtÞ ð57Þ
It should be noted that the coefficients of excitation amplitude and damping were assumed to be small and in the same order as the displacement. To achieve this purpose, in Eq. (58) the following assumption is considered e e2ge, f e3gf . These assumptions can be verified physically for this problem; furthermore, a small amplitude of excitation leads to calculating only the primary resonance frequency [63]. Hence, Eq. (57) can be written as:
€r þ G1r þ G2er3 þ G3e r _r2 þ r2€r þ G4e_r ¼ f ecosðXtÞ ð58Þ
where
G1 ¼ ba ; G2 ¼ c a ; G3 ¼ da ; G4 ¼ e a ; f ¼ f a ð59Þ
To begin the solution of the equation, the following expansion is presented [62]:
rðT0; T1Þ ¼ r0ðT0; T1Þ þ er1ðT0; T1Þ þ ::: ð60Þ
The scaled times can be introduced as
T0 ¼ t; T1 ¼ et ð61Þ
Eq. (58) is the function of time and not time scales. For converting the ordinary differential equation to the function of
time scales, the chain rule can be used. So, the first and second derivative operators can be formulated as:
d dt ¼ D0 þ eD1 ð62Þ
d2 dt2 ¼ D20 þ 2eD0D1 ð63Þ
where
Dn ¼ ddTn ð64Þ

e0 : D20r0 þ G1r0 ¼ 0 ð65Þ

r0 T0; T1ð Þ ¼ AðT1ÞeixT0 þ A ðT1Þe ixT0 ð67Þ

By substituting Eq. (67) into the right side of Eq. (66), this equation can be written as:

sections.heading: 3.2. Stability analysis
sections.text:
The stability of the system can be determined by linearizing the system and finding the eigenvalues of the Jacobean matrix in the fixed points [64]. Linearizing the system can be obtained as Eq. (89):
A ¼
@m1 @x1 : : : @m1 @xn @m2 @x1 : : : @m2 @xn
: : : : :
: : : : : @mn @x1 : : : @mn @xn
2 66666664
3 77777775

ð89Þ
It should be said that denotes the fixed points.
m1 ¼ f x sin cð Þ G4 2 a T1ð Þ ð90Þ
m2 ¼ rþ f ax cos cð Þ þ a 8x a2 ð91Þ
x 1 ¼ a ; x 2 ¼ c ð92Þ
By substituting Eqs. (90)–(92) into Eq. (89), the Jacobean matrix can be written as:
A ¼ G4 2 a rþ aa 2 8x
1 a rþ 38xaa 2 G4 2
2 4

s ¼ G4 ð94Þ
D ¼ G 2 4 4 þ rþ 3 8x aa 2 rþ aa 2 8x
ð95Þ
where s and D are the trace and determinant of matrix A respectively. System stability can be determined with regard to the sign of s and D. The damping coefficient (G4) is always positive and hence s is always negative. This means if D > 0, the fixed point can be a stable spiral or a stable node, but if D < 0, the fixed point is a half-stable saddle node.

sections.heading: 4. Numerical results
sections.text:
In this section, the numerical results for the nonlinear forced vibration of the cantilever microbeam are presented. The microbeam considered here consists of silicon (Si) and piezoelectric (Zno) with the material and geometrical properties Eb ¼ 170GPa, hb ¼ 800nm [52], lb ¼ 592nm [65] for Si, and Ep ¼ 133GPa, hp ¼ 400nm [52], lp ¼ 0 [66], L1 ¼ 0, L2 ¼ L for Zno. Also, L ¼ 500 lm and b ¼ 100 lm are the same for Si and Zno. It should be noted that absorption of the biological layer will be considered by an arbitrary sample [67]. Hence, Lennard-Jones constants can be given as A ¼ 1:3 10 72jm6, B ¼ 0:4 10 135jm12 [52] and the mass of biolayer msð Þ can be neglected compared to the total mass of the structure [51,67].
The frequency-response curve has been plotted in accordance with Eqs. (85) and (86). Fig. 4 shows this diagram before absorbing the biological layer for classical theory. It should be noted that the figure for the pre-absorption state and classical theory is plotted when the material length scale parameter and biological potential energy are both set to zero. In addition, the frequency-response curve in the linear case is plotted by setting the a to zero. It can be seen that nonlinear resonance occurs at the excitation frequency, which is different from the linear case. this is one of the most important events in nonlinear vibrations. Another point that can be seen from this diagram is the softening effect on the nonlinear frequencyresponse curve, so that Resonance occurs at smaller resonance parameter relative to the linear case, which is due to the presence of nonlinear terms in kinetic energy. By neglecting the nonlinear expression in kinetic energy, the diagram will show
hardening behavior and will bend to the right. Additionally, it should be noted that according to Eq. (87), the maximum amplitude, is not function of the nonlinear coefficient (a). This is confirmed in Fig. 4.
Fig. 5 shows the change in the excitation frequency versus the amplitude of the response. It can be seen that in the nonlinear frequency-response curve, unlike in the linear curve, the region that is between two normal tangents is multi-valued. However, the responses depend on the initial conditions and the stability of the system.
Fig. 6 shows the change in the frequency ratio (X=x) versus the amplitude of the response after and before the absorption of the biological layer for linear and nonlinear regimes. Clearly, the absorption of the biological layer has a stronger effect on softening behavior.
Fig. 7 shows the change in frequency caused by absorption of the biological layer. It is clear that absorption of the biological layer makes the microbeam stiffer and causes the frequency to increase. Comparison of Fig. 7 and Fig. 6 indicates that the absorption of the biological layer on nonlinear behavior has a softening effect, though on the entire structure it has a hardening effect. As expected and in accordance with Eqs. (85) and (86), the absorption of the biological layer will also affect the amplitude of the response, but this is so low (4.9704 nm) that in Fig. 6 it is not even visible.
Fig. 8 illustrates the frequency-response curve before absorbing the biological layer based on the couple stress theory. The main difference between this figure and Fig. 4 is the significant change in the frequency and amplitude of the response. So, the couple stress theory reports a higher frequency and less amplitude than the classical theory. This indicates the hardening effect of couple stress on the structure, which is explicitly mentioned in most of the research in the literature review.
Fig. 9 compares two nonlinear frequency-response curves based on the classical and couple stress theories. Although the couple stress theory increases the amount of a, because of an overall significant decrease in the amplitude it has a lower softening effect as compared to classical theory.
Fig. 10 shows the change in couple stress-to-classical frequency ratio versus the thickness-to-material length scale parameter ratio. As expected, by increasing the thickness of the beam, the difference between the two theories is reduced so that after the ratio of 10, the two theories have almost the same results. Hence, couple stress theory has a larger bending rigidity but will be ignored when the material thickness increases. The reason for this becomes obvious upon comparing the bending rigidity of the classical and couple stress theories. Due to an increase in material thickness even as the length scale parameter of the material is constant, the expression lAl2 becomes smaller than the EI and the effect of the couple stress theory decreases.
Fig. 11 shows the change in frequency caused by biological layer absorption based on couple stress theory. The change in frequency in the couple stress theory is less than the classical theory because the flexural rigidity in the non-classical theory has increased. A full comparison of the frequency variation based on these two theories will be considered in Table 2.
In Table 1, the sensor sensitivity for length reduction is studied using the classical and couple stress theories. As expected, a decrease in the length of the beam increases its vibration frequency; however, unexpectedly, this increase in frequency does not reduce the sensitivity of the sensor. The reason for this is the distribution of biological material over the length so that the decrease in the length of the beam and the biological material occurs simultaneously, and despite the increase in the frequency of vibration sensitivity in the both theories stays constant.
In Table 2, the change in sensor sensitivity due to a decrease in the thickness of the structure based on classical and couple stress theory is investigated. The results show that reducing the thickness reduces beam frequency and increases sensor sensitivity. It should be noted that an increase in sensitivity in couple stress theory is mild due to the increase in flexural rigidity.
It can be clearly observed from Table 3 that before absorption, the frequency is independent of width variations. However, the reduction of width leads to an increase in the frequency after absorption and causes an increase in sensitivity. Also, unlike the reduction in thickness, the effect of reduction in width does not affect the flexural rigidity due to the couple stress theory.

According to the Fig. 4, it seems that the difference between the linear and nonlinear resonance frequencies is very small and can be ignored. However, change in the frequency of resonance and the asymmetry frequency-response curve have other consequences, which can be mentioned as multivalued responses, changing of system stability, and jump phenomenon. All of these are important results of nonlinear analysis. According to Eq. (94), for D < 0, the system is half-stable. This happens in the frequency-response curve in the range between the two vertical tangents shown in Fig. 5. Therefore, the points of the beginning and ending of the dashed line in Fig. 12 can be considered as the bifurcation points of the system, in which the stability of the system is changed and the fixed points of the system created and destroyed (saddle bifurcation) [64].
For explaining the jump phenomenon, one can imagine that an experiment is performed in which the amplitude of excitation is held fixed. So, in accordance with the path specified in Fig. 12, with an increase in the resonance parameter, the system response will reach the ‘A’ bifurcation point. At this point, a slight increase in the resonance parameter will lead to a jumping of amplitude from point ‘‘A” to ‘‘B”. This event also occurs on the return path by reducing the resonance parameter. It is clear that the jump down is larger and more significant as compared to the jump up.
Moreover, it should be noted that the jump phenomenon only occurs due to the physics of the problem and not because of the half-stable region. This confirms the fact that the system does not experience the half-stable region through the paths. Since the half-stable fixed point is stable for an initial condition and unstable for other conditions, it is expected that in the range between the two vertical tangents the response will be on the dashed line only for a specific initial condition of the domain. The system gets attracted to the high or low points of the half-stable point only for a slight deviation from this condition. Therefore, the half-stable region will not be problematic in this issue.
It is important to note that the aforementioned features of nonlinear systems can be used for the detection of biological material in biosensors [68,69]. In this way, the beam must be vibrated at a frequency equal to the frequency of the bifurcation point, so that the absorption of the biological layer leads to a sudden jump in the amplitude and, hence, the objective of the biological sensor can be achieved. It was observed that the absorption of the biological layer has an incremental effect on the natural frequency; hence, the resonance parameter is expected to decrease due to the absorption of the biological layer. Therefore, the system should be vibrated at the ‘C’ bifurcation point so that it reacts to the absorption of the biological material.
Fig. 13 can be used from Ref. [69] to validate Fig. 12 qualitatively. Fig. 13 resulted from an experimental study on biosensors. It can be seen from this figure that softening behavior and the jump phenomenon are qualitatively in agreement with Fig. 12.
Fig. 14 shows the amplitude change and nonlinear behavior of the system versus an increase in the damping coefficient. Significantly, with an increase in the damping coefficient, the amplitude decreases naturally. Since, according to Eqs. (85) and (86), nonlinear behavior is dependent on the amplitude, so that a decrease in amplitude causes the system to behave linearly. This makes it impossible to view the bifurcation points and the jump phenomenon of the amplitude. Therefore, in the case of selecting the jump strategy for detecting the biologic material, the damping coefficient (environment) and amplitude should be chosen to facilitate the achievement of the biosensor objective.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this paper, the nonlinear vibration of the micro/nano cantilever beam covered with piezoelectric and biological layers was studied. The governing equations were presented by the skew-symmetric couple stress theory. Finally, the equation of motion, with regard to small displacement, damping coefficient, and amplitude of excitation was solved by multiple scales method. The most important results are listed below.
The nonlinear geometry mentioned in this problem causes softening behavior in the frequency-response curve. Biological absorption causes more nonlinear behavior (deviation to the left). The absorption of the biological layer makes the microbeam stiffer and causes the frequency to increase. The consequence of nonlinear behavior in couple stress theory is weaker than classical theory. The couple stress theory predicts the structure will be stiffer; hence, its amplitude is smaller and its frequency is larger than classical theory. By increasing the thickness to the material length scale parameter ratio, the results of the two theories come closer. After the ratio of 10, the results of the two theories approximately are the same. Reducing the dimensions except length will increase the sensitivity of the biosensor, though this increase is mild in case of thickness reduction in the couple stress theory. The sensitivity of the biosensor to the absorption of biological material in the theory of couple stress is less than classical theory. For detecting biological material using the jump phenomenon, the vibration frequency of the beam should be equal to the up bifurcation point. Increasing the damping and decreasing the amplitude leads to the tendency of nonlinear to linear behavior and prevents the biosensor from detecting biologic material based on the jump phenomenon.

referenceMentions.context: The use of common clinical methods has limitations, such as response time and the high cost of doing operations; therefore, the development of an efficient method as a diagnostic tool and biological molecular identification technology is required [1,2].

The use of common clinical methods has limitations, such as response time and the high cost of doing operations; therefore, the development of an efficient method as a diagnostic tool and biological molecular identification technology is required [1,2].

The strategy of cantilever biosensors is based on two approaches: the static approach, which is based on the bending measurement influenced by the surface stress caused by absorption, and the dynamic approach, in which the concentration of a sample is obtained by measuring the variation in the resonance frequency of the beam caused by the absorption of biological material [3,4].

The strategy of cantilever biosensors is based on two approaches: the static approach, which is based on the bending measurement influenced by the surface stress caused by absorption, and the dynamic approach, in which the concentration of a sample is obtained by measuring the variation in the resonance frequency of the beam caused by the absorption of biological material [3,4].

Cantilever-based sensors, which are based on static approach often have several advantages over dynamic mode, but to identify the mass in order of a single molecule only the dynamic method can be used in a nanoscale beam [5].
It should be noted that among the three key metrics of sensors which include response time, selectivity, and sensitivity, only the last case is dependent on the identification scheme [6].

According to the results of numerous experiments [13], it can be confidently said today that the effect of the interactions of micro/nano structures (the origin of the couple stress theory) is not negligible.
On the other hand, experiments show that the effects of nonlinearities are very significant on the behavior of nano and micro-mechanical tools even in the absence of large deformations [27].
